question:
Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of an 8-week history of blood in his stool. Two months ago, he had an episode of bronchitis and was treated with amoxicillin. Since then, he has noticed blood in his stool and on the toilet paper occasionally. The patient has had intermittent constipation for the past 5 years. Six months ago, he had severe left lower quadrant pain and fever that resolved with antibiotic therapy. He underwent a colonoscopy 3 years ago, which did not show any evidence of malignancy. He takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years, but quit smoking 10 years ago. He drinks one glass of red wine every night. He appears pale. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 36В°C (96.8В°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly. Digital rectal examination shows no masses. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 76 Ојm3
Red cell distribution width 17% (N = 13вЂ“15)
Leukocyte count 5,000/mm3
What is the most likely diagnosis?". If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: In this 70-year-old man with an 8-week history of visible blood in the stool and on toilet paper, stable vital signs (temperature 36°C [96.8°F], pulse 85/min, blood pressure 135/80 mm Hg), and a positive fecal occult blood test, the presence of pallor with pale conjunctivae and iron-deficiency indices (hemoglobin 11 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 76 µm3, red cell distribution width 17% [N = 13–15]) indicate chronic lower gastrointestinal blood loss. The abdominal examination is benign (soft, nontender, no organomegaly), digital rectal examination reveals no masses, and leukocyte count is normal (5,000/mm3), arguing against active inflammatory colitis. The patient’s 5-year history of intermittent constipation, obesity (BMI 32 kg/m2), and a prior episode of severe left lower quadrant pain with fever 6 months earlier that resolved with antibiotic therapy are consistent with underlying diverticular disease (prior diverticulitis) in the sigmoid colon. In older adults with diverticulosis, bleeding typically results from erosion or rupture of the vasa recta at the dome or neck of a diverticulum and presents as painless, intermittent hematochezia, often with iron deficiency. A colonoscopy 3 years ago without evidence of malignancy reduces the likelihood of colorectal cancer as the current source. The clinical and laboratory profile most strongly supports a colonic diverticular source of bleeding. The most likely diagnosis is Diverticular bleeding.
content.source_2: An elderly male (age 70 years) presenting with 8 weeks of hematochezia, a positive stool occult blood test, and iron-deficiency anemia (hemoglobin 11 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 76 µm3, red cell distribution width 17% [N = 13–15]) has a high pretest probability of lower gastrointestinal bleeding from diverticulosis, particularly in the context of obesity (BMI 32 kg/m2), chronic constipation (5 years), and a documented episode of severe left lower quadrant pain with fever 6 months prior that resolved with antibiotic therapy (consistent with antecedent diverticulitis and implying underlying diverticulosis). He is afebrile (36°C [96.8°F]), hemodynamically stable (pulse 85/min, blood pressure 135/80 mm Hg), without abdominal tenderness or organomegaly, and has no masses on digital rectal examination; his leukocyte count is normal (5,000/mm3), which argues against an active inflammatory or infectious colitis. Amoxicillin exposure 2 months ago for bronchitis does not explain the current bleeding in the absence of diarrhea or systemic toxicity. Colonoscopy 3 years ago without malignancy further reduces the likelihood of neoplasia as the source of chronic blood loss. This constellation is characteristic of bleeding arising from colonic diverticulosis. The most likely diagnosis is Diverticulosis-associated bleeding.
content.source_3: The patient’s clinical course fits within the spectrum of diverticular disease manifesting as hemorrhage: a 70-year-old man with obesity (BMI 32 kg/m2) and a 5-year history of intermittent constipation had severe left lower quadrant pain with fever 6 months ago that resolved with antibiotics, consistent with prior diverticulitis (and thus confirmed diverticular disease), and now presents with an 8-week history of blood in the stool and on toilet paper. He appears pale with pale conjunctivae; fecal occult blood testing is positive; and laboratory evaluation shows iron-deficiency anemia (hemoglobin 11 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 76 µm3, red cell distribution width 17% [N = 13–15]) without leukocytosis (leukocyte count 5,000/mm3). He is afebrile (36°C [96.8°F]) and hemodynamically stable (pulse 85/min, blood pressure 135/80 mm Hg), the abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly, and digital rectal examination shows no masses. A colonoscopy 3 years ago did not reveal malignancy, lowering the likelihood of a neoplastic source. In older adults with established diverticular disease, bleeding typically presents as painless hematochezia due to erosion of the vasa recta within a diverticulum, resulting in chronic iron loss. The temporally remote amoxicillin exposure for bronchitis 2 months ago does not account for the bleeding in the absence of diarrhea or systemic illness. Taken together, these findings are most consistent with the hemorrhagic phenotype of diverticular disease. The most likely diagnosis is Bleeding diverticular disease.
